Award.AwardTitle: Achieving in Research, Math, And Science (ARMAS) Scholarship Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The Achieving in Research, Mathematics and Science (ARMAS) Scholarship Program provides $10,000 per year for up to a three-year period to three cohorts of four New Mexico Highlands undergraduates majoring in biology, chemistry, environmental geology or forestry. The financial support will enable students to work off-campus less and focus on attending school full-time during the last years of their studies. Integrated with financial support, students receive enhanced academic and career support services, faculty mentorship, and peer support. Each semester the ARMAS scholars participate in an interdisciplinary, problem-based seminar that incorporates the acquisition of skills required of scientists - how to pose questions, delve into the existing literature, design experiments, find collaborators, use new instruments, develop protocols, collect and analyze data, and summarize and present results. Throughout the scholarship period, guidance is provided to ensure a smooth transition into a career or graduate program in their field. NMHU is an open enrollment institution serving a large rural population characterized by diverse cultural, economic, linguistic, and educational backgrounds. The ARMAS Scholarship Program addresses the needs of these students and the NSF S-STEM goals by improving educational opportunities and increasing retention for STEM students, consequently addressing retention and graduation rates in the biology, forestry, environmental geology and chemistry disciplines at a Hispanic-Serving Institution in rural northern New Mexico.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Achieving in Research, Mathematics and Science (ARMAS) Scholarship Program was designed to provide effective financial and student support services to address the needs of upper level students majoring in Biology, Chemistry, Environmental Geology and Forestry at New Mexico Highlands University (NMHU), an open-enrollment Hispanic Serving Institution located in rural Northern New Mexico.  Founded in 1893, NMHU has an historical commitment to providing affordable, accessible education to populations traditionally underserved in higher education. The ARMAS Scholarship Program addressed factors affecting academic persistence and the effectiveness of providing financial resources after the sophomore year to academically talented students with financial need.  The financial support provided students the opportunity to work less while attending school full-time during the last two to three years of their studies. Coupled with financial support, enhanced academic and career support services, faculty mentorship, and peer support were integral components. The ARMAS Scholars also participated in an inter-disciplinary, problem-based seminar offered each semester.

The design of the ARMAS Scholarship program was built on the concept that students who are able to devote time to their studies, develop a close connection with their campus community and participate in a cohort of students with a common goal are most likely to persist in STEM.   A key feature of the ARMAS Scholarship Program was faculty mentoring integrated in the weekly cross-disciplinary, project-oriented seminar provided throughout the Scholarship period. 

The program was initially designed to support three cohorts of four students per year to become part of the diversified STEM workforce needed by our nation.  However, due to timely graduations and leveraging of resources, the program was able to expand to support twenty-three students.  Of the twenty-three, sixteen have completed their STEM degrees and are either now in graduate school or working in STEM fields. Six of the expanded cohorts are still completing their degree. To date only one student has chosen not to complete a degree and is now running her own business.

The S-STEM funding provided by NSF allowed NMHU to provide opportunities for academically-talented STEM students with financial need to participate in research and summer programs instead of working off-campus while attending college.  These students served as role models for siblings, extended families and other students as well as confirming the belief that their teachers and families have that their students can achieve great things if opportunities are available. The broader impact of the project was to provide resources to talented, financially needy students that supported successful completion of STEM degrees in order to broaden perspectives and representation in STEM fields.
